results.title: Pandamonium
results.creator_credit: Academy of Interactive Entertainment (AIE) and Daniel Riddle
results.brief_description: A bad tempered stuffed panda is plucked from the window display of a toy store by a sweet little girl. 3-D computer animation. Original score composed by Chris Lam Sam.

results.title: The Lunar cycle
results.creator_credit: Academy of Interactive Entertainment (AIE) and Kai Faigenbaum
results.brief_description:
A man on a unicycle travels above the sleeping city on a cloudy night, sweeping darkness away to reveal a new moon. This 3D animated fable offers a new interpretation of the term ‘lunar cycle’.
Music by Andy Statman.

results.title: 'Servent' solves a problem
results.creator_credit: Ivor P. Kershaw and Factual Films of Australia
results.brief_description: A demonstration of how a newly-developed system of wiring between your house and the main electricity supply may be used to eliminate unsightly masses of wires between your home and the poles in the street. (Sponsored by Olympic Cables.)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ivor P. Kershaw and Factual Films of Australia

results.title: 'Justice' of the Red functionaries
results.brief_description: Inspired and colourful narration accompanies this montage of German propaganda designed to illustrate the worst tyrannies of a Soviet State. Shows the administration of justice in 1948 as applied under Ulbricht’s communist regime. Includes pictures taken in Soviet zonal courts, and interviews with judges who fled to the West. An example of cold-war era red-scare demagoguery.

results.title: Man of Flowers
results.brief_description: Norman Kaye won the AFI’s best actor award for this stunning portrayal of Charles Bremer, a strange and sensitive man, whose sensual appreciation of all things beautiful led to his bizarre and erotic relationship with a young bi-sexual named Lisa. “Man of Flowers” is both erotic and richly amusing with a tragic after glow.
results.description: Norman Kaye won the AFI’s best actor award for this stunning portrayal of Charles Bremer, a strange and sensitive man, whose sensual appreciation of all things beautiful led to his bizarre and erotic relationship with a young bi-sexual named Lisa. “Man of Flowers” is both erotic and richly amusing with a tragic after glow.

results.title: Yolngu boy
results.creator_credit: Stephen Johnson, Gordon Glenn, Patricia Edgar, Burrundi Pictures and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Caught in a collision between the modern world of rap, football, and street cred and the oldest living culture on earth, Lorrpu, Botj and Milika are three Yolngu teenagers who once shared a childhood dream of becoming great hunters together. But things have changed and their paths are diverging. Botj is walking on the wild side, a lost soul in search of a place to belong. Milika is more interested in football and girls than any of the traditional knowledge he is being taught. Only Lorrpu seems to care about the dream any more. Their paths are diverging, and he is the only one who can see it.

When Botj goes too far and finds himself on the wrong side of both black and white laws, Lorrpu must weigh up his own future against saving his friend.

He persuades the boys to trek to Darwin to argue Botj’s case with Dawu, a tribal leader. Leaving behind their community, they journey through the unforgiving wilderness of north-east Arnhem Land to Darwin. To survive, Lorrpu, Milika and Botj must draw on the ancient bush knowledge they were taught as boys and, most importantly, the bonds of their friendship.

Yolngu Boy is about the search for identity, making the journey from adolescence to adulthood and the implications of belonging to a larger social group, whether it is a culture, a family or a group of friends.
